segments.text: Hello everybody, I'm Lou Dobbs and welcome to the Great America Show. Good to have you with us
as we fight for truth, justice, and the American way. There's no doubt this week that the country's
careening between one crisis and the next and the nation is without a doubt in decline. And there's
little evidence that decline is in any way manageable. Only a fool would think those crises are
anything but orchestrated. A hardly stealthy Chinese spy balloon that Biden permits to float
over our secret bases coast to coast for a week. The obvious alliance that Biden struck up with the
Mexican drug cartels and the 2000-mile border that they now control or the conspicuous weaponization
of the entire federal government against decency, the rule of law, the American way of life, our
heritage, our history, and our values. Nothing about these crises is normal or natural.
The indictment of President Trump has arrest with even some of the Marxist dims saying it's
enough. Stop. Guess who might have been listening? The most liberal appellate court in the nation,
the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which on the same day that President Trump was indicted
by the Manhattan DA, ruled that porn star Stormy Daniels had to pay President Trump
121,972 dollars in legal fees from a 2018 defamation lawsuit that she lost. Our guest is an icon in
American law. He once represented President Trump in his first impeachment for which the left has
never forgiven him. Our guest is Alan Dershowitz, attorney, Harvard Law Professor Emeritus,
and author of the new book Get Trump. Alan, great to have you back with us here on The Great America
Show. Let's begin with the indictment, a historic and dark document. Your thoughts on its adequacy
and its likelihood of survival. I've been reading indictments for 60 years, teaching at Harvard Law
practicing, I've never read an indictment like this. You can read it over and over and over again,
and there's just no crime. Here's the basic theory on the line the indictment. Donald Trump
allegedly paid $130,000 in hush money to make sure that a plumb of porn star doesn't reveal to his
wife, his friends, his voters, his business associates, etc. That they had an adultress
affair. The purpose of the money was to keep quiet, to make sure it doesn't become public.
And Brexit, in order to avoid being prosecuted for felonies in New York, he then immediately had
to go and publicly disclose on an open corporate form the fact that he paid the hush money in
order to keep people quiet and prevent the public from learning it, has there ever been so ridiculous
acclaim in the history of America from the day that Alexander Hamilton paid his hush money to
prevent an adultress affair from coming out. There have been thousands and thousands of hush
money payments never in the history of the country. Has anybody ever been prosecuted for not then
putting it on a public form? Why would anybody ever pay a nickel and hush money if they then had
to report, oh, I paid the hush money to prevent from coming out when I'm now going to put in a
public record? It is absurd. I can't even say it without smiling.
Do you think that the courts will smile as well? Perhaps chuckle when they see it?
No, not the courts in New York City, not the courts in Manhattan. The courts in Manhattan know
this is an injustice, but no judge in New York elected judges in New York. No judge in New York is
going to be the guy who walks around town with people pointing the finger at him saying,
that's the man that freed Donald Trump. How do I know that? Because I defended Donald Trump once
in the floor of the Senate and nobody in Manhattan would talk to me, nobody on Martha's
Vineyard would talk to me. I became the devil incarnate, but just because I defended him once,
can imagine how much more so that would be for a judge who freed him, who actually freed him,
you know, a robe doesn't give you courage. And no judge would have the courage to throw this
indictment out, even though they all know that it's not worth the paper, it's written on.
Including the judge, Judge Merchant in the court in New York when that indictment was handed down.
No, he's not going to have the courage to do that. You know, he has family connections to the
Democrats. He's just not going to do it. Even if he knows he's going to be reversed, he'd rather
blame the people upstairs in the court of it wasn't my fault. Those damn judges up in Albany,
they reversed it. They're the ones who freed Trump. I didn't free Trump. No, nobody wants to be the
one responsible for frame Trump in the borough of Manhattan. In the borough of Manhattan,
you cannot get a fair trial. Remember, Brad ran and won the DA on the promise to get Trump.
Now he wants the very people who voted for him to get Trump to serve on the jury to determine
whether he has in fact gotten Trump. I mean, if somebody wrote a novel about this, it would be
rejected for being too ridiculous. But that novel came true in the courthouse where I have
practiced for many years in New York. And it was a sad, sad, sad day.
Well, it says pretty sad day right now. Historic event, a dark event in this country's history,
and I think you agree with me on that. And the reality here is New York has been
become something unto itself. In addition to all of the evil we see in the partisanship and the
ideological conflict that grips its nation, we're, we're balkanizing the country on the basis of
Marxist ideology, if you wish, progressive partisan politics or conservative politics.
We really, you know, it's one thing to say this about Manhattan and New York,
that they are entitled to their ridiculous politics. But I can't excuse it. And I don't
think the judicial system or words should do it.
It's getting worse. It's getting much worse, not better. Why? Because the future leaders of the bar,
the future judges, the future professors, are now at Stanford Law School, at Yale Law School,
at Georgetown Law School, stopping people from speaking, saying that the Constitution doesn't
matter, that it's a white male, a patriarchal document and should be ignored. There are now
100 chapters of the National Lawyers Guild in law schools around the country. What's the
National Lawyers Guild? It started as a communist front-to-organization. It supported Hitler when
the Stalin made the pact with Hitler. The Soviet Union told the to do so. It supported Israel in
1948 because the Soviet Union told to do so. It then rejected Israel in 1967 because the Soviet
Union told it to do so. And so you have this woke progressive, hard, hard, hard left,
becoming more and more influential in law schools. And by the way, the 100 chapters of the National
Lawyers Guild have a lot of professors in them as well. And so we're seeing our next generation
of leaders today are in the elite law schools are being taught to disvalue the Constitution
and to put politics, ideology and partisanship above it. In my book Get Trump, I go through
all of this and I go through the history of how we got there. And I go through all of the four
counts that are now being investigated against Donald Trump and show this nothing to any of them.
And if the shoe were on the other foot, if these were investigations being done at Hillary Clinton
or Joe Biden or Hunter Biden, everybody would be on a different side. All these progressives would
be saying, Oh my God, what a terrible distortion of justice. But now they're rooting for injustice.
They're rooting for violations of liberties. Well, they are rooting and cheering. And at this point,
there is very little that suggests to me, at least, that President Trump is going to have an easy
time of it. I know that his one of his lawyers, Joe Tackapino says he doesn't believe this case
will get near a jury. But if it does, you know, God help the president because they don't want to
give up venue. They don't want to give up jurisdiction over this case because he is there about enemy,
he being Donald Trump, your thoughts. I look, I think this case will get to a jury because I don't
think judges will have the courage to throw it out. And I think the jury will convict a member.
The jurors will be the same people who voted for Alvar Bragg. And the judges will be the same
people who voted for Alvar Bragg, many of them. If there's a change of venue, things could be
different. If the case, there are two motions that can be made early on that might be appealable,
might be appealable. One is the change of venue motion and the other's substantial limitations.
And if they're made quickly, they'll be denied by this judge, but they can then be taken up to
the court of appeals before there's any trial. But I do think we're going to have a trial here.
I don't think we're going to see this case dismissed without a trial, although that would be the right
thing to do. Should we have anything at all in the New York appellate courts? Are they any better
than the Supreme Court's first jurisdiction? Well, it's a divided Supreme Court. I mean,
it's called the New York Court of Appeals. It's divided. It has Republicans and Democrats, so
at least there'll be some dissenting views. But the Supreme Court of the United States, I think,
will ultimately not tolerate this. But it'll take the good part of a year to get to the United
States Supreme Court, even on an expedited basis. And by that time, we're well into the presidential
campaign. This is the first time in history. Forget about the fact that it's the first time in history
that a form of president has been died. The first time in history that a current presidential candidate
has been indicted. And I think it was the president of San Salvador. I'm not sure one of the South
American countries who said yesterday in a tweet, don't lecture us about democracy anymore. You're
prosecuting and threatening imprisonment of the man who's running against your incumbent president,
and you're lecturing us about democracy. The United States has lost its standing to talk about
democracy as a result of some local DA who promised to get Trump. The title of my book,
Trump is not original with me. It's completely plagiarized from the campaign promises of Laetitia
James and Alvin Bragg. And that's the campaign to get Trump beyond New York, spread all over the
country. And we're going to see, and then we're going to see some pushback. We're going to see
some local Republican DAs trying to get Hunt to Biden, trying to get other Democrats. And it's
going to destroy the neutrality and objectivity of our legal system, which is a great tragedy.
It is a tragedy. It's a tragedy that is not only unfolding before our very eyes,
but taking root throughout. I think it's, by the way, I want to compliment you on the book,
get Trump. I don't think I've seen him more timely, not even from you, a more timely title. And you are
sagacious in your timing, as well as your interpretation of law and politics. But I recommend
the book to everyone, Get Trump by Alan Dersawitz. But there is in this now, I think has to be a
recognition on the part of our thought leaders are our leader. Once leaders in business, academia,
you name it, that this country is now contending with a new force, something we've never seen
in this expanse. And that is a Marxist force within the Democratic Party that has taken hold
and now controls the federal government. And we have to acknowledge that. I don't think we can
get much done. Do you not agree? I do not agree. And that's why I'm remaining a Democrat to fight
from within the Democratic Party. I think there is an effort to do that. I don't think it has yet
succeeded. And I'm going to fight back. I'm almost 85 years old. I have been a Democrat all my life.
I'm a Democrat, not because of any particular person, because I support a woman's right to choose,
gay marriage, reasonable gun control, reasonable climate control, separation of church and state.
I buy the Democratic agenda over the Republican agenda. But I don't buy the effort to try to push
the Democrats into the kind of woke progressive extremism that we're seeing happen. My greatest
enemies, by the way, are not conservatives at all. They are the radical left. That's the people
that I fight against every day. And I'm trying, trying to prevent the Democratic Party from becoming
what you've described as being. I don't think it's there, but I think there's a risk it could become
that. And I think it's important for people like me, the few remaining Democrats who believe in a
more centrist and libertarian approach to fight from within until we've given up. I'm not ready to give
up. Well, we've heard this audience has heard Alan Dersowitz icon of American law say that you
can't trust the courts of New York. You cannot trust the the Marxist DIMMS. And it's a even,
at best an even bet on the appellate courts. We know in the federal courts that we've got
almost a thousand people who've been incarcerated, some of them in prison for two years without trial.
We have seven years of personal political persecution of a president without so much as a yawn from the
left or the progressive Democrats or even if there is such a remaining thing, a moderate Democrat.
It is we have to acknowledge what it is. The woke madness is his his permeated
every department in the federal government. There is no exception.
Whether it's the IRS, the Department of Defense, the Department of Justice, the FBI, the IRS,
I mean, this I just don't find an exception to the domination of the Marxist DIMMS and the
Democratic Party in alignment with the deep state that control the federal government.
Look, I think there are two events that have occurred over the last a few years that have
transformed America for the worst. One was the election of Donald Trump
and then the loss of Donald Trump, but the whole Donald Trump phenomenon which created
Trump derangement syndrome. People with just nuts. You can't talk to them. Larry David runs up to
me on show mark. We've been friends for years. I helped his daughter get into college. We,
you know, we come to my house for dinner. He works out in my gym. Screams and yells at me. I'm
discussing I'm despicable. There's that syndrome. And then there was the murder of George Floyd.
That turned America into an identity politics country where every branch of government now must
must make reparations for the horrible evils of slavery. And it's permeated every institution of
America, the Academy, the media corporate America, political America. You cannot today say, I believe
in racial equality. You cannot quote the Bible that says don't recognize faces or implicitly
don't recognize races or genders. Everything turns on identity politics today. And those two events
are transformative events. And people have taken sides. You can't have a conversation.
In the middle, you can't say, look, you know, Donald Trump, as I've said, did a great deal of good on
the Middle East. The Abraham of course is fantastic. The recognition of Jerusalem. The goal on
heights. I played a small role in some of these events. I worked with President Trump. I admire
that. I think that's great. I don't like his views on ABCD. You can't say that anymore. Or you can't
say, look, it's important to increase the number of minorities in universities. But let's not do
it through racial quotas. You can't say that anymore. There's no middle ground. That's what I worry so
deeply about. And in my book, Get Trump, I propose middle grounds. I propose ways of dealing with
some of these issues that don't hand over the narrative through the extreme extremes on the
left of the extreme extremes on the right. And where would we find such bipartisanship, such moderation
that we would accommodate the Marxist Dems who are demanding control of this country and the
reversal of our heritage or values, whether it be Judeo-Christian culture that has created all of
this. I can tell you where to find them. I can tell you where to find them. At the ballot box.
Okay, you find it at the ballot box because I think that when radical right or radical left
people run for office against good moderates, they tend to lose, not always, but they tend to lose.
America is a centrist country. We need centrist leaders. We need courageous leaders who are willing
to lose the votes of the extremes on either side and say, look, America is a country in the middle.
You can be a liberal conservative. You can be a conservative liberal. You can be a moderate.
You could be a libertarian, but we have to marginalize the extremes on either side. And that's what
I've been setting up for all my life. That's what I'm going to spend whatever the good Lord gives
me left of my life to fight for moderation, Americanism. When I walk into my house every day,
my little apartment in New York, I turn to a wall in the entry place. And I see an original copy,
an early copy of the Declaration of Independence. I see an early copy of Tom Payne book. I see an
early letter from George Washington. I see a letter from Alexander Hamilton from Jefferson from Lincoln.
These are the people who are inspiring. These are the people who keep me going. I want to make sure
that the values that they created for America, separation of powers, checks and balances,
remain the central part of our constitutional democracy.
I admire your idealism. I admire your patriotism. I think it's wonderful. But I know right now,
anyone in this country listening to this show and to you who is a Marxist dim just said,
my God, he recited how many names, founding names of this nation who own slaves and
should, you know, as part of the national original sin. That is the way they view the world.
And when you talk about the way they do it, and we have to fight back and we have to tell them that
the Declaration of Independence did not include the right of property in the declaration because
Jefferson didn't want to permanently the ownership of slaves. These are complicated issues. Washington's
wife owned slaves, but he didn't. Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation. Not everything he
said about blacks was perfect. A perfect is the enemy of the good. And we've had phenomenal
leaders and I fight for our legacy. And my family loves America. We've been here since 1889.
We were rescued from the programs of Europe. So many Americans were rescued from discrimination
bias and bigotry. We don't want to see it return to America. It's too late. Alan, it's here.
This is there is systemic racism. There is systemic extremism. And it is
mostly, mostly if not predominantly on the left. And we
I'm fighting it on the left because that's my tradition. And that's where I come from. That's
where I have to fight the fight. And I think people on the right should fight the fight
against extremism on the right. I wish that every progressive in the country would follow the
standard that you carry repair to that standard. And the country is on its way to to salvation.
But right now, Donald Trump, you are made it almost sound like it was Donald Trump's fault,
but that there was Trump. No, no, it's a phenomenon. No, it's a phenomenon that he was in part
responsible for in the sense that he was the person who said I'm running against the establishment.
I'm running against the deep state. I'm running against this. You know, he's a provocative person.
You can describe provocative in neutral terms. I'm not blaming it on him. I'm just
attributing part of it to him. Yeah. And I think that because he is Donald Trump,
he stood up for America first for balanced trade. The withdrawal of our troops from foreign remote
outposts and postings that he should be applauded by the left because I'm a product of the 60s.
I remember when that was a serious issue for the left. They want our troops at home.
And moderates wanted a modest foreign policy. That is precisely what Donald Trump offered America
and was rejected. Maybe not at the ballot box, but by a rigged election as Donald Trump
predicted in May of 2020. All I want is nuance, moderation, recognize the goods of every side,
every side, and some goods to say, you know, I even agree with what President Trump said when
he went to Charlottesville, he was talking about people who don't want to tear down the monuments.
And in that context, he said, there are good people on both sides. There are bad people on both sides.
And of course, that was totally misunderstood and misinterpreted. There are good people
not on every side, not for every issue. Obviously, the people who marked in Charlottesville saying,
we want to replace them, et cetera. Those aren't good people. But there are good people who don't
want to tear down the monuments. I'm among them. I want to move them to museums, perhaps,
where they can be subject to education and teaching. But I want moderate solutions.
And that's what I'm opting for. Unfortunately, one of my moderate solutions
requires me to leave in a minute because I have another obligation. But it's always a pleasure
to return to your show, which I had so many good times on in past years. And I hope you continue
educating America for many, many more years.
We're going to take that as your concluding thoughts, Alan. And you're leaving us with
the inspiration to find moderation. I hope that that can be achieved. I am highly skeptical,
as you probably have inferred long ago. I'm a skeptical person as well. But my final message
is please buy my book, Get Trump, because that will send a powerful message to Bragg and others.
There are people out there watching him. There are people out there holding him accountable.
Alan Dershowitz, a great American. Thanks, everybody, for being with us.
Here tomorrow, Republican strategist and pollster John McLaughlin on the extraordinary polling
numbers for the 45th president. Please join us here tomorrow. Till then, God bless you, God bless
America.
